title: Strictly Come Dancing star Johannes Radebe says show helped him 'accept' himself
text:
He credits the dancing competition with allowing him to feel comfortable with himself (Picture: WireImage)

Johannes Radebe has praised Strictly Come Dancing for helping him to become more ‘accepting’ of himself.

The 32-year-old dancer – who was partnered with Catherine Tyldesley on the BBC show – grew up in South Africa, where he was bullied due to his sexuality.

However, he’s admitted that starring on the hit show has proven to be a liberating experience.

Johannes – who was subjected to homophobic bullying during his childhood in South Africa – told The Sun newspaper: ‘I’ve always known. I’ve always been proud. I’ve always been myself, regardless of what was said to me and where I come from.

Catherine and Johannes became the fifth couple to be eliminated from Strictly Come Dancing (Picture: BBC)

‘I grew up in a country where homosexuality was frowned upon.

‘The society around me pointed to me and said, “There’s something wrong with you.” But Strictly has helped me be a better person and accepting of myself.’

Johannes and Catherine became the latest shock elimination on the show after the pair landed in the bottom and became the fifth couple to exit the dance floor after a split decision between the judges in an intense discussion.

Johannes however, remains in good spirits, and explained that the Strictly bosses were eager for him to be himself on the screening.

He said: ‘I’ve done Strictly a couple of times in other countries, but when I got here the production team told me to put on heels and strut around – and that’s my job!

‘That’s huge for me, because that’s something that would never have happened in South Africa.’

He and his partner had been up against firm favourites to leave the competition, Mike Bushell and Katya Jones, but they failed to impress with their Cha Cha to Scared Of The Dark by Steps for Halloween.

Strictly Come Dancing continues Saturday at 7pm with the results show on Sunday at 7.15pm on BBC One.
